abstract: The stars of Spike's new home-renovation show are personable enough, but "Flip Men" feels as if it could fall into predictability: flip men buy house; flip men are appalled by condition of house; flip men moan about how much money they're going to lose; flip men miraculously turn a profit.
snippet: The stars of Spike's new home-renovation show are personable enough, but "Flip Men" feels as if it could fall into predictability: flip men buy house; flip men are appalled by condition of house; flip men moan about how much money they're going to...
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has roamed through television's renovating/make-overing/house-flipping genre probably has been struck with the notion that the most appropriate tool for attacking some of the featured projects is a bulldozer. That is certainly a likely response to the opening episode of "Flip Men," Tuesday night on Spike. When you have to rip as much out of a house as ends up being ripped out here, maybe you should have just torn the danged thing down.
